Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a field emission scanning electron microscope for multidisciplinary nanotechnology research
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical abstract:

The acquisition of the proposed instrument, i.e. a high resolution field emission scanning electron microscope, will dramatically upgrade the capabilities for surface characterization and analysis existent at Cleveland State University (CSU). The high resolution imaging capability of the microscope (~ 1nm at 30 kV) together with its analytical tools that include back-scattered electron detection, and energy dispersive X-ray mapping, will help an interdisciplinary core of researchers from CSU and neighboring institutions to continue building a comprehensive program in nanotechnology. Some of the research programs currently ongoing for which the instrument will provide much needed infrastructure include: (i) fabrication of hybrid metal - semiconductor nanostructures for light emission applications; (ii) nanostructured materials for hydrogen storage; (iii) characterization of minerals and artifacts of antiquity; (iv) characterization of thermally responsive polymers; (v) biomedical applications of microfluidics; (vi) development of nanocomposite materials with improved mechanical and electronic properties; (vii) strain-tolerant self-sensing environmental barrier coatings for ceramic composites; (viii) nanocomposite materials for supercapacitors; (ix) nanostructured catalysts for biological detection; and (x) structure analysis of lipoproteins. Additionally, the imaging infrastructure will create the opportunity to introduce nanotechnology as part of the educational experience offered to our science and engineering undergraduates and graduate students, and K-12 partners.

Non - technical abstract:

Understanding and exploiting for practical applications the unique phenomena of materials with nanoscale dimensions requires the ability to characterize their geometry on scales down to 1 nm. The proposed high resolution microscope will provide vital morphological and also analytical information for projects ranging from structural mechanics to life sciences. This infrastructure will support the work of researchers from the departments of Physics, Chemistry, Mechanical Engineering, Electrical Engineering and Chemical and Biomedical Engineering, across two colleges at CSU. Work using the facility includes not only projects from CSU, but also from neighboring institutions, such as the Cleveland Museum of Natural History. Likewise, the availability of the instrument will have a great impact on our courses with material in nanotechnology and surface characterization, and will allow our faculty to expand the research programs offered to our undergraduate and graduate students. Also, through our school partners the high resolution microscope provides an ideal platform to provide experiential learning on the properties of matter on the nano and microscale for K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of the activity funded by the grant was the acquisition, installation and maintenance of a high resolution field emission microscopy facility targeted at sustaining efforts in developing a comprehensive nanotechnology program at Cleveland State University (CSU) and neighboring institutions. The state of the art microscopy tool installed as part of this grant provides high resolution morphological and chemical mapping for projects ranging from the characterization of high performance materials, to tissue engineering and the development of state of the art sensing technologies. Over the course of the grant period the sponsored microscopy facility has enabled research work on more than ten independent research projects.

Intellectual Merit: The major instrumentation funding provided under the current grant, has supported the research work of a growing core of CSU researchers that in the last decade have built an innovative research portfolio in the investigation of micro- and nano-scale systems, with applications ranging from structural mechanics to life sciences. The projects that have critically relied and continue to rely on extensive access to the high spatial resolution imaging and analytical tools enabled by this NSF funding include: (i) characterization of highly anisotropic nanoparticles (Image 1); (ii) fabrication of hybrid metal - semiconductor nanostructures for light emission applications; (iii) development of denoising algorithms for low dose electron microscopy (Image 2); (iv) fabrication of materials for bone scaffolds (Image 3); (v) characterization of thermally responsive polymers; (vi) biomedical applications of microfluidics; (vii) development of nanocomposite materials with improved mechanical and electronic properties; (viii) strain-tolerant self-sensing environmental barrier coatings for ceramic composites; (ix) development of biofilms for converting biochemical energy into electrical energy (Image 4); (x) nanostructured catalysts for biological detection (Image 5); (xi) structure analysis of lipoproteins; (xii) analysis of neural cell systems; and (xiii) characterization of directed self-assembly of colloidal systems.

Broader Impacts: Through the broad range of research projects enabled, the sponsored laboratory infrastructure has proved a fertile ground for promoting interdisciplinary collaborations. Over the years the projects pursued have brought together researchers from a variety of fields: physics, chemistry, nanoscience, energy, mechanical, manufacturing, chemical engineering, and geology. From CSU, the various research projects enabled have involved  faculty and both undergraduate and graduate students from the Departments of Physics, Chemistry, Mechanical Engineering, Electrical Engineering and Chemical and Biomedical Engineering, across two colleges. The availability of the NSF sponsored microscopy facility has also provided students with a unique training opportunity on state of the art instrumentation. More than 20 PhD or master students are or have been directly involved in research projects that make extensive use of scanning electron microscopy. Moreover, the facility has been extensively used in classes focused on nanotechnologies and instrumentation and as part of the CSU programs for undergraduate research, further expanding the number of students whose career development has been impacted. For many of these students we believe that the skills gained were critical in becoming successful professionals in the manufacturing and emerging technologies job market in Northeastern Ohio. Expanding the research infrastructure present at CSU has served not only its research community and students, but also our community partners.
